bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, May 9, 1928

div1.p: Kean sends Agramonte a Congressional committee report on the yellow fever pension bill and gives his opinion in regards to compensation amounts. Kean also comments on the Rockefeller Foundation yellow fever work in West Africa.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Aristides Agramonte, May 9, 1928
div1.opener:
9 May, 1928.
Dr. Aristides Agramonte,
Calle K. Entre 15 y 17
Vedado, Habana.
My dear Dr. Agramonte:
div1.p:
I am sending you herewith a report of the Committee on Military
Affairs on a Bill to recognize the services of the Reed Yellow Fever Board
and the men who volunteered for experiment by giving them or the families
of those who died an annuity of $5000 per year. You will see that in
the report I have seen to it that your services as a member of the Board are
set forth fully and fairly. I hope that something will come out of this,
although I think it is rather doubtful.

It seems to me as it does to General Ireland that it is absurd
to give the men who slept in infected bedding as great a reward as is given
to the members of the Reed Commission, or their widows; as General Ireland
told Mr. Wainwright it is like giving the Commanding General and the
private in the ranks the same pension. However, some good may come of it.
As I told Mr. Wainwright, my concern is that the members of the Reed Board
should be properly taken care of, and so this is done I do not greatly
object to their giving the volunteers for experiment just as much as
they wanted.

General Ireland's proposition was that the members of the Reed
Board (Or the families of those deceased) should get an annuity of $3000;
those in the second category who had yellow fever should get $2000, and
those in the third category who slept in infected bedding should get $1200.

Have you seen the report of the Rockefeller Board about yellow fever
work in West Africa? Their experiments have knocked Noguchi's leptospira
icteroides higher than a kite. You have noticed that they found all animals
immune, except some Asiatic monkeys; the African monkeys are all immune.
It is too bad about the death of Dr. Adrian Stokes Russell tells me that he
got his infection while inoculating monkeys with the blood of monkeys ill of
yellow fever.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J.R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd. JRK/B
